DOC.HEAD: Repairs on High-Tech Drug Planes Delayed
DOC.TEXT: Heeding the warnings of two senators, the U.S. Customs Service says it won't buy a third high-tech radar plane until the two existing problem-plagued aircraft can locate and track airborne drug smugglers. In a letter released Monday the Customs Service acknowledged, however, that the computerized radar systems in the P3 Airborne Early Warning aircraft won't be fixed until June _ half a year after the most recent estimate. The planes are the government's frontline response to intercepting drug flights, which carried an estimated 51 percent of the cocaine seized during 1988 to the United States. The Associated Press reported in November that the radar systems experienced problems since the moment the first plane arrived in June 1988 at the Customs Service Surveillance Support Center in Corpus Christi, Texas. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Pete Domenici, R-N.M., wrote to the agency Nov. 12, saying a third plane should not be ordered ``until the two ... aircraft currently being operated ... meet the overall aircraft performance standards originally intended...'' DeConcini is chairman and Domenici the ranking minority member of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that controls the Customs Service budget. The planes are made by Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Co., which predicted in November the problems should be corrected around the end of this year. The first-of-their-kind planes were designed to find and track smuggler aircraft and guide government interceptors chasing the drug pilots _ but internal agency documents revealed that computer failures severely hampered this mission. However, the planes have continued flying while the Customs Service attempted to fix the problems. In response to the senators, William Rosenblatt, the Customs Service assistant commissioner for enforcement, wrote, ``We will not enter into a contractual agreement for the third aircraft until such time as ... we are entirely satisfied that the originally intended performance standards are met'' and until the senators give their approval. Rosenblatt's letter was written last week and released to the AP Monday by DeConcini. The senator, a strong advocate of the airplanes, said in a statement that he's satisfied the Customs Service ``has responded in a responsible manner'' and has ``established a schedule to rectify the deficiencies.'' ``I am satisfied,'' he said, that the agency is insuring ``the viability of the air interdiction program while insisting that the contractor live up to the terms of the contract.'' The first P3 AEW cost $27 million and the second was bought for $30.6 million. If the third plane is ordered, it would be expected in 1992. ``Everyone was being a little optimistic'' in estimates that the problems would be fixed by the end of this year, agency spokesman Dick Weart said Monday. ``Extensive testing'' by Lockheed will take longer than anticipated, he said. Rosenblatt said the agency is withholding $1.5 million from Lockheed until the detection system is fixed and until the company also replaces the cockpit windshields _ a separate problem that has hampered pilot visibility. Rosenblatt said Lockheed is attempting to fix: _The ``tracker'' which automatically provides computer displays on a target's course, speed and altitude. Radar operators have complained the readings are so inaccurate that they can't effectively guide Customs Service interceptors to a smuggler aircraft. Some crewmen said they worried they could direct their interceptors into a collision with a smuggler aircraft. _The system used by the P3 AEW planes to ``interrogate'' the transponder signals of other aircraft to determine their identification and location. The P3 interrogation signal is so powerful that planes that may be 300 miles away appear on computer screens as nearby targets. _The special windshields, built to prevent magnetic interference from the radar. The windshields originally installed have interfered with pilot visibility.
